awd_titl_txt: Allosteric Interactions between Proteins on DNA and Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
The regulation of genes in cells is controlled by the binding/unbinding of proteins on DNA. Often, the binding of one protein changes the binding affinity of a different protein at a distant site on the DNA molecule. This phenomenon is called "allostery"; it has been extensively studied in enzymes, but not through DNA which has mostly been regarded as a rigid object that provides binding sites for proteins.  Allostery through DNA has been implicated in many previous experimental studies, including in the binding of drug molecules, but it has not been understood through a mechanical theory which regards DNA as an elastic (not rigid) molecule that is locally deformed by the binding proteins. Similar elastic deformations caused by proteins binding to lipid bilayers also result in allosteric interactions that are responsible for cellular processes, such as, endo- and exo-cytosis required for transport of materials into and out of cells. Often, allostery also involves entropic forces between the proteins that are the result of fluctuations caused by Brownian motion of the elastic media (DNA or lipid membrane) separating them. The overall goal of this research program is to quantitatively describe allosteric interactions between proteins on DNA and lipid membranes through a mathematical theory that regards them as elastic objects while accounting for their Brownian fluctuations.  The model will significantly improve understanding of how genes are regulated in living cells. The project will include instruction of graduate students, mentoring of undergraduates and masters students.  The PI will also perform outreach through  organizing symposia and advanced schools in international conferences, and working with the Penn MRSEC and the Nano Bio Interface Center for NanoDay and other activities targeted at high school (minority) students and teachers.

This project will advance the fundamental understanding of allosteric interactions through DNA, thus addressing long-standing open questions in the field and providing quantitative explanations for the wealth of experimental data on the subject. In particular, this project will show how a birod model for DNA can describe the deformations caused by proteins at a single base-pair level, and how the energy due to these deformations is sinusoidally modulated due the helical nature of DNA. For proteins on lipid membranes this project will show how self-assembly may be caused by the competition of their elastic and entropic interactions. The new theoretical approaches developed in this project will enable quantitative predictions of allosteric interactions between proteins as a function of the mechanical properties of the DNA or membrane and the boundary conditions imposed on them by the binding proteins. The analysis performed in this project will place allosteric interactions of proteins on DNA and lipid membranes in the broader context of theories for the interactions of defects in elastic solids.

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are biomolecules that perform all the important processes of life. They are the building blocks of molecular machines and the structural components of cells. Proteins bind to DNA and decode the information encoded in genes. Proteins are present on cell membranes and they regulate the traffic of molecules into and out of the cell. Proteins and/or molecular machines must interact with each other in order to perform their functions. One way they can interact is through direct mechanical contact with each other, but biology is replete with examples of proteins interacting with each other even when they are situated far apart while bound to DNA or lipid membranes. The research in this award was focused on unraveling the mechanism of this `non-local? interaction between proteins.

For proteins bound to DNA we showed that interactions over distances of a few tens of basepairs occurs due to mechanical deformations of the DNA itself that are caused by the binding of proteins. This idea could explain the experimentally measured change in rates of binding/unbinding of proteins to DNA in the presence of another protein bound some distance away. Modeling the elastic deformations of DNA required thinking of it as a ?birod?. A birod is a mathematical object consisting of two rods that are connected to each other through a series of links, like a ladder. The two rods and the links can deform when forces and torques are applied on them (by the proteins) and this creates a deformation field that decays exponentially with distance from the point of application of the forces. If some other protein binds in the region of influence of one of the proteins then its actions and binding/unbinding rates are affected by the elastic deformation of DNA caused by the first protein. We explained these effects for the first time through a mathematical model in two papers, one published in the Proceedings of the Royal Society of London A and another in the Journal of Physical Chemistry. We also used the birod model to explain the physics of DNA melting by thermal and/or mechanical means and published this in a paper that appeared in Soft Matter. These papers and several others formed the PhD thesis of Dr. Jaspreet Singh.

For proteins on the surface of lipid membranes it was already known that interactions occur due to elastic deformations of the membrane and due to thermal fluctuations that cause entropic interactions. Eventually these interactions result in clustering of the proteins. We modeled the rates of clustering using methods of statistical physics. Our major contribution was a computational method that accounts for elastic and entropic interactions of a number of arbitrarily shaped proteins and their diffusion on the surface of the membrane. We also developed mathematical methods that could capture the kinetics of the clustering process without recourse to expensive and time consuming computer simulations. Papers on these topics were published in the Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids and in Soft Matter. It is important to understand the clustering of proteins on membranes because viruses assemble in this way and exo- and endo-cytotic transport of molecules through cells involves clustering of the transporting proteins. The statistical physics methods developed for this project were employed also in studying the force-stretch relations of microscopic filaments immersed in a bath containing active agents (such as, prevails in the cytoplasm of a live cell). This work was published in the Journal of Chemical Physics. These papers formed the PhD thesis of Dr. Xinyu Liao.

Since some funds still remained after the above research was completed we obtained permission for a change of scope of the project and funded an undergraduate student who performed experiments on the evolution of tension in polymerizing fibrin networks. Fibrin networks are the main structural component of blood clots which need to be under tension in order to perform their function of closing wounds. While the first two projects delved into the effects of mechanics on biochemistry of proteins, this third project did the opposite ? it showed how biochemical processes (polymerization) can lead to mechanical effects. The research performed in this project was published in the Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials. This paper formed a chapter of the PhD thesis of Dr. Russell Spiewak and the summer research of UG student Mr. Danil Merinov.

The funds from this grant also enabled travels of the PI and his students to several conferences where they presented their research and learned about the work of other colleagues.
